title: Aperol Spritz
description: This simple recipe, listed on the back of the Aperol bottle, is one of the most refreshing summer coolers.
method: Add everything to a chilled rocks glass, then fill with ice. Stir and garnish with half an orange wheel.

title: Bee's Knees
description: In the 1930, when Frank Meier was tending the Ritz bar in Paris and creating simple, sophisticated cocktails like this one, calling something Bee's Knees was quite a compliment.
method: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish.
source: Frank Meier, The Artistry of Mixing Drinks, 1937

title: Caipirinha
description: According to cocktail historians Jared Brown and Anistatia Miller, "Caipirinha" is a Brazilian word used to describe a "country bumpkin".
method: Muddle the lime and sugar. Add the cachaça, then shake with ice and pour unstrained into a chilled rocks glass. No garnish.

title: Daiquiri
description: Charles H. Baker claims his friends Harry Stout and Jennings Cox created the Daiquiri in a village of the same name situated outside the Bacardi plant in Santiago de Cuba.
method: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lime wheel.

title: El Diablo
description: Trader Vic's revised bartender's manual devoted 9 pages to tequila drinks, 8 more than any other significant cocktail book of the century.
method: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with ice. Garnish with a lemon wheel and candied ginger.
source: Jules Bergeron, Trader Vic's Bartender's Guide, 1972

title: Flying Dutchman
description: An ancestor of the Aviation Cocktail, the name references Dutch genever, not the cursed ship forever lost at sea.
method: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with one brandied cherry.

title: Gimlet
description: The Gimlet may have been named after British Royal Navy Surgeon General Sir Thomas Gimlette, who took his scurvy inhibitor with a tot of gin.
method: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lime wheel.
source: Harry McElbone, ABC of mixing Cocktails, 1922

title: Hotel D'Alsace
description: David Slape named thi drink after the post Parisian hotel where Irish scribe and spirits devotee Oscar Wilde spent his last years.
method: Add the Cointreau, Bénédictine, and bottom half of rosemary sprig to a mixing glass and muddle. Add Bushmills and ice, then stir and fine-strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with the tip of the rosemary sprig.

title: Improved Whiskey Cocktail
description: In "Imbibe!" David Wondrich traces the evolution of the plain whiskey cocktail to more evolved versions such as the Fancy Whiskey Cocktail in the 1862 edition and the Improved version above, which appeared 14 years later.
method: Stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled, Vieux Pontarlier Absinthe-rinsed rocks glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Jack Rose
description: One of the many hypothesis surrounding the name of this drink is that it is a corruption of Jacquemont, a pink rose with a similar hue to this drink.
method: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish.
source: William Boothby, The World's Drinks and How to Mix Them, 1908

title: Kansai Kick
description: Using the Cameron's Kick cocktail as a template, John deBary substituted malt whiskey aged on Japan's Kansai plain in place of its Celtic brethren, used lime in place of lemon juice, and added a little Madeira for complexity.
method: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish.

title: Left Hand Cocktail
description: Sam Ross combined his favourite classics, Italy's Negroni and America's Manhattan, into one drink and named the result after Lefty, an Italian-American character from the movie Donnie Brasco.
method: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with 3 brandied cherries on a pick.

title: Martini
description: Over the last hundred years, the preparation and choice of garnish of this protean cocktail has been one of the most accurate methods to measure the palate of an era.
method: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with three olives on a pick or a lemon twist.

title: Negroni
description: The combination of gin, sweet vermouth and Campari showed up as the Camparinette and the Campari Cardinal in French and Spanish cocktail books such as "Cien Cocktails" and "L'Heure du Cocktail" before being recognized universally as the Negroni.
method: Stir with ice and strain into chilled coupe or over ice in a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with an orange twist.

title: Old-Fashioned Whiskey Cocktail
description: In 1806, the word cocktail was defined in the "Balance and Columbian Repository" newspaper as a "stimulating liquor, composed of spirits of any kind, sugar, water and bitters - it is vulgarly called a bittered sling..." By 1888, the cocktail as defined above was already old hat!
method: Muddle, stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.

title: Pisco Sour
description: The Pisco sour was first served by Californian Victor Morris, who substituted Pisco for whiskey in the sours served at his bar in Lima, Peru.
method: Dry-shake, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled egg coupe. Garnish with 4 drops Angostura Bitters switled with two straws.
source: Charles H. Baker Jr., The South American Gentleman's Companion, 1951

title: Queens Park Swizzle
description: Swizzles are traditionally prepared with a barspoon-length dried branch from a tropical bush that has five pruned prongs at the end.
method: Muddle mint leaves and demerara syrup in a chilled Collins glass. Add rhum, lime and pebble ice, then swizzle and top with more pebbled ice. Add 2 dashes 2 dashes Peychaud's Bitters and 2 dashes Angostura Bitters. Garnish with a mint sprig.
source: Jules Bergeron, Trader Vic's Bartender's Guide

title: Rusty Nail
description: According to David Wondrich, the B.I.F. cocktail, composed of Scotch and Drambuie, first appeared in 1937. Now known as the Rusty Nail, the recipe under this name didn't appear in popular cocktail books until the 1970's.
method: Stir with ice and strain over a large cube into a chilled rocks glass. No garnish.

title: Sidecar
description: According to Vermiere, this cocktail "was first introduced by MacGarry, the celebrated bartender of Buck's Club" in London.
method: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled, half sugar-rimmed coupe. No garnish.
source: Robetr Vermiere, Cocktails: How to Mix Them, 1922

title: Tom Collins
description: This cocktail was named after John Collins, a waiter at Limmer's Hotel in London, who was famous for his gin punch.
method: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice. Top with 2 oz. Club Soda and garnish with a lemon wedge.

title: Up To Date
description: Ensslin calls for Sherry Wine in the recipe, leaving the style open for interpretation. While an Oloroso would work nicely, Manzanilla lends vibrant salinity and bracing acidity.
method: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist.
source: Hugo Ensslin, Recipes for Mixed Drinks, 1916

title: Vesper
description: This Martini hybrid, named after Bond's love interest in Casino Royale, is largely culpable for a generation of imbibers thinking that spirituous drinks should be shaken, not stirred.
method: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Granish with a lemon twist.

title: White Lady
description: You can still order McElbone's creation at Harry's New York Bar in Paris from one of the bar's old-school, white-coated barmen.
method: Dry-shake, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled egg coupe. No garnish.
source: Harry McEllbone, ABC of Mixing Cocktails, 1929

title: Zombie Punch
description: Tiki bar owners like Donn Beach went through a lot of trouble to keep their recipes a secret: only the most trusted stuff members knew the full recipes, which were batched secretly and given to the bartenders on the front line to mix out of numbered bottles.
method: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled tiki mug filled with pebble ice. Garnish with a mint sprig.
